intro: Ramium caudatum, commonly known as the hairy leek, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and dill, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters, featuring slender stems and compound leaves with a distinctive hairy texture. Its small, white or pale yellow flowers are arranged in umbels, typical of the Apiaceae family. Ramium caudatum is often cultivated as a ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and mild, garlic-like scent.
